poem:
**Sixteen's Dawn**

In the cool bloom  
of barely grown life,  
pollen drifts of choice  
settle on young palms—  
a ballot, a breath.  
Footsteps echoing  
over cobbled futures,  
the worn paths widen.  
To cast in paper,  
new voices humming  
beneath an ancient sky,  
cradled by centuries'  
hopeful murmur.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Join the army, work full-time … and now vote: what 16-year-olds can do in the UK Turning 16 opens up a whole suite of exciting new freedoms. Now, those celebrating their baby steps into adulthood in the UK have another thrilling task for their to-do lists: heading to the voting booth. Thursday marked one of the largest changes to the country’s democratic system in recent times after Labour announced the voting age would be lowered". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Join the army, work full-time … and now vote: what 16-year-olds can do in the UK Turning 16 opens up a whole suite of exciting new freedoms. Now, those celebrating their baby steps into adulthood in the UK have another thrilling task for their to-do lists: heading to the voting booth. Thursday marked one of the largest changes to the country’s democratic system in recent times after Labour announced the voting age would be lowered
